generate_data_spatial¶

Module for generating synthetic spatial data.

utils.generate_data_spatial.assign_features(base_grid, feature_params)¶

Automatically assign features to a grid using a constrained uniform distribution.

Parameters

  • base_grid – 2D grid of target values

  • feature_params – dictionary containing feature generation parameters. Should include “num” (number of features to generate/feature vector dimensionality), “max” (maximal value of the uniform distribution), “min” (minimal value of the uniform distribution), “correlation” (correlation coefficient between random features and the target variable).

Returns

3D feature grid

utils.generate_data_spatial.create_grid(grid_height, grid_width, global_mean, global_std, stationary=True, nonstationary_points=None)¶

Creates a 2D-grid of specified height and width using N(global_mean,global_std). If stationary is True, the grid will be stationary, i.e., the mean and std will be constant throughout the grid. If stationary is False, individual points will be computed using the mean and std from the list of nonstationary_points.

Parameters

  • grid_height – height of the grid to be generated

  • grid_width – width of the grid to be generated

  • global_mean – global mean for values in the entire grid

  • global_std – global standard deviation for values in the entire grid

  • stationary – Boolean denoting whether the grid should be stationary

  • nonstationary_points – list of nonstationary points, where individual points are dictionaries with keys ‘coords’ = (y,x), ‘mean’ = local mean, and ‘std’ = local standard deviation.

Returns

generated grid (no spatial autocorrelation)

utils.generate_data_spatial.find_val(grid, cell_coords, neighbour, h, w)¶

Function for the easy access to neighbouring values in a grid-based representation.

Parameters

  • grid – grid to work with

  • cell_coords – current cell indices

  • neighbour – direction of the neighbour (“top”, “down”, “left” or “right”)

  • h – height of the grid

  • w – width of the grid

Returns

returns the value of a neighbour, if it exists, False otherwise

utils.generate_data_spatial.generate_nonstationary_points(num_points, grid_height, grid_width, min_mean, max_mean)¶

Generates random nonstationary points within specified constraints.

Parameters

  • num_points – number of nonstationary points to generate

  • grid_height – height of the target grid

  • grid_width – width of the target grid

  • min_mean – minimum local mean value

  • min_mean – maximum local mean value

Returns

list of nonstationary point dictionaries

utils.generate_data_spatial.hide_values_uniform(base_grid, probability)¶

Return a new version of the supplied grid where values are probabilistically (uniform) hidden.

Parameters

  • base_grid – 2D grid of target values

  • probability – probability to hide an individual cell

Returns

copy of base_grid with some artificially hidden cells

utils.generate_data_spatial.update_grid(grid, ac_params, grid_height, grid_width, isotropy=True, anisotropy_autocorr=None)¶

Apply an update to the specified grid to ensure spatial autocorrelation.

Parameters

  • grid – grid to work with

  • ac_params – dictionary of autocorrelation parameters, should include the keys “iterations” (number of times to call the update function), “autocorrelation” (autocorrelation coefficient), “static” (Boolean denoting whether AC is static or not). If static==False, also include “mean” (mean AC) and “std” (AC std).

  • isotropy – Boolean indicating whether grid should be isotropic or not

  • anisotropy_autocorr – if isotropy==False, dictionary of directional AC coefficients (“top”, “down”, “left” and “right”)

Returns

grid updated with autocorrelation
